item.description:
Meeting #3 of the Theoretical Computer Science Problem-Solving group is scheduled for Fri. 9/25/09 at 7PM at Wagamama 57 JFK in Harvard Square, Cambridge. We will begin by ordering supper or appetizers. Then there will be a talk on the results of Kurt Godel in 1931 and Alan Turing in 1937. This will be followed by a general discussion. Some specific points:

1. What did Godel and Turing prove?

2. How did they prove it? Are there other proofs? What is the simplest possible proof?

3. What were the later contribution of others e.g. Rosser in 1936 and Smullyan for the past 50 years?

4. What does it mean to Logic? Mathematics? Science? Computer Science? Theoretical Computer Science? Artificial Intelligence? Philosophy?

5. Does it place limitations on doing real Mathematics?

6. Does it say something about the inherent abilities of man vs. machine?

7. How do the results of Godel and Turing actually relate to each other?

8. In what ways are Logic/Axiomatic Systems equivalent to computer programs?

9. Can we translate Godel’s theorem into a statement about computer programming? Can we translate Turing’s theorem into a statement about systems of Logic?

10. How do Godel and Turing’s theorems relate to simple but extremely difficult mathematics problems like proving Fermat’s Last Theorem or Goldbach’s Conjecture?

This will be followed by an open forum for anyone who would like to discuss some question or problem of interest. We will discuss them and perhaps devote a future meeting to the topic. Always feel free to send in your own suggestions for topics or attend the meeting to voice your interests.

Wagamama has long simple tables that allow lots of people to converge and have a lively discussion – like all of the meetings we have had so far.

Hope to see everyone there, with their ideas and profound discoveries in Theoretical Computer Science!

Charlie
item.how_to_find_us: I will be at the right end with a notice on the table.
item.name: Theoretical Computer Science Meeting #3. Godel & Turing: Theorems & Implications
